abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Primary Education
            Project for Bhutan are as follows: overall outcome of the
            project was rated satisfactory, sustainability prospects was
            considered as good, and performance of the Bank and the
            Borrower was rated as satisfactory. Some of the lessons
            learned are: 1) lengthy initial implementation delays
            largely attributed to civil works point to the importance of
            careful start-up planning and implementation; 2) the Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU's) steady integration within
            division of education (DOE) enhanced implementation and
            increased efficiency and has helped to foster borrower
            ownership; 3) high quality external training courses and
            well matched fellowship placements pay dividends over
            lower-cost options; 4) like other projects of the time,
            there were no monitor able indicators per se, although the
            end objectives were largely used to assess progress by Royal
            Government of Bhutan (RGOB) and missions, particularly at
            the mid-term review (MTR) stage; 5) to achieve sustainable
            skills transfer from technical assistance experts, it is
            critical that national counterparts are carefully identified
            and selected. International experts should also be carefully
            chosen to ensure they are capable and willing to adapt to
            local conditions and relate effectively with their
            counterparts; and 6) the DOE' s reluctance to
            compromise on teacher quality for the sake of expediency is
            noteworthy and has sent a strong message to the system.

18150136.subsc: Sub-natl govt admin,Tertiary education,Primary education,Central government administration
18150136.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Education for all,Other public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Primary Education Project supports
            the Government's development plan for primary education
            and aims to raise the quality of education and student
            achievement and lower unit costs of primary schooling in
            Bhutan.  Specifically, it seeks to (a) increase the number
            and quality of primary schools; (b) increase the number and
            effectiveness of primary teachers; and (c) strengthen
            administrative and educational support services of the
            Department of Energy (DOE).  To that end, the project
            consists of three specific components:  (a) primary school
            development, (b) teacher training institutions and (c)
            educational administration.  In addition to financing the
            construction of school and teacher training facilities, the
            project intends to finance 8.4 staff-years of technical
            assistance and 17.8 staff-years of fellowships and
            placements, as well as some vehicles and equipment.
